WORKERS' RIGHTS AND OBLIGATIONS

Table of Contents

 

Victoria and Western Australia  

 

In Western Australia, four levels of offences exist, with a maximum penalty of $625,000 for repeat corporate offenders, or $312,500 and two years' imprisonment for repeat individual offenders.

 

In Victoria, penalties vary depending on the type of offence. For a breach of an employer's duty to employees for example, an individual can be fined $215,010 while corporations can be fined $1,075,050 (indexed yearly).

 

 

Liability of corporations

 

Corporations, (generally, a person, association or group of persons) can be liable for WHS offences committed by officers or employees of the corporation. A corporation will be considered to have engaged in certain conduct if it was engaged in by an:

 

•         employee of the corporation (acting within the scope of their employment)

•         agent or officer of the corporation (acting within their authority)

 

Click here for more information

There are three categories of WHS offences an individual or corporation can commit.

 

Click the three categories below for more information

 

Category 1 offence

 

A person commits a category 1 offence if they:

 

1.

owe a health and safety duty

2.

expose an individual to a risk of death, serious injury or illness through their conduct

3.

are reckless to this risk

 

Example: A supervisor directs a worker to move a number of heavy boxes that obstruct the walkway, even though the supervisor knows that the employee is suffering from long-term damage to his back.

 

Category 2 offence

 

A person commits a category 2 offence if they:

 

•

owe a health and safety duty

•

fail to comply with that duty

•

expose an individual to a risk of death, serious injury or illness

 

Example: A large number of contractors are brought in to help finish a busy job. There isn't enough desk space so a few people are working from the store room. While checking on the contractors, one of the staff members trips over a loose wire, hits a cabinet and is seriously injured.

 

 

Category 3 offence

A person commits a category 3 offence if they:

 

•

owe a health and safety duty

•

fail to comply with that duty

Example: A company allows a culture of bullying in an office and does not take any steps to prevent workers from being put at risk of psychological injury from the bullying.
